newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Yeltsin may leave hospital next week - spokesman.
newsitem.headline: Yeltsin may leave hospital next week - spokesman.

text.p: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is likely to leave hospital in the next few days and attend a summit of former Soviet republics planned later this month, the Kremlin said on Friday.
"It (Yeltsin's departure from hospital) will be in the next few days, but not at the weekend," presidential press secretary Sergei Yastrzhembsky told a news briefing.
"We assume that he will take part in the CIS summit," he added, referring to the meeting of the heads of state of the 12-member Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) planned for January 29.
Yastrzhembsky said that Yeltsin, taken to hospital with pneumonia on January 8, was recovering well and had even taken part in an impromptu celebration of his daughter Tatyana's birthday .
He said Yeltsin worked three hours on Friday, preparing his annual address to parliament and considering draft documents and decrees.

"If things continue like this, meetings with the premier can start next week," Yastrzhembsky said about regular consultations between Yeltsin and Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, traditionally held on Tuesdays.
Yeltsin, who turns 66 on February 1, had multiple heart bypass surgery in November but doctors say this is not connected with the pneumonia.
They have so far been reluctant to set a date for Yeltsin to leave the elite Central Clinical Hospital, warning that pneumonia is a serious illness which carries the risk of possible complications.
But recent statements have had an optimistic tone, and doctors say the president's condition has stabilised.
"We have no reason to think that the doctors' optimism is unfounded," Yastrzhembsky said.
He added: "The president is certainly interested in recovering as quickly as possible. But I think it is natural to ... show some patience to give him the chance of a recovering completely."
